Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Keats Conley of University of Oregon to conduct a research project in Biology during the summer of 2013 at Hiroshima University in Hiroshima Prefecture, Japan. The project title is "Behavior and Survival of Moon Jellyfish (Aurelia aurita) Larvae Under Various Environmental Conditions." The host scientist is Dr. Shin-ichi Uye.

Moon jellyfish (Aurelia aurita) mature in June-August in Hiroshima Bay and release free-swimming larvae called "planulae." This study investigates the behavior and survival, or physioecology, of planulae under various environmental conditions (temperature, salinity, dissolved oxygen, light). Planulae are also eaten by common filter feeding organisms, such as oysters, mussels, and tunicates. This research measures the feeding rates on the planulae by these organisms. Since larvae generally have very high mortality rates, environmental factors such as these can have large impacts on survival, subsequently affecting adult jellyfish abundance. This work carries social and economic significance because some regions have experienced increasingly frequent and severe jellyfish blooms, which present a grave threat to some fishing industries, aquaculture farms, tourism and coastal industry. In Japan, blooms of moon jellyfish have imposed significant costs on fisheries by clogging and bursting fishing nets. In the U.S., the notorious "slime bank" of the Bering Sea is seasonally unfishable because of jellyfish abundance; blooms, therefore, present a global economic threat, not just a national one.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, results from this EAPSI research collaboration on jellyfish larval response to different environmental parameters may ultimately be used to help predict variations in populations, conveying societal benefits by helping various industries to manage the socioeconomic damages imposed by jellyfish. The EAPSI host researcher is a member of a national counter-jellyfish project (STOPJELLY), leading the development of new technology to predict and control jellyfish outbreaks; through this collaboration, the EAPSI fellow is acquiring exposure to such technologies, which may ultimately have applications for coastal management and policy. This project also helps enhance the average citizen?s scientific understanding of jellyfish by using the Newport Aquarium, which attracts over 40,000 students each year, as a site for a public display on the significance of research findings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project sought to assess how exposure to low salinity (“hyposalinity”) affects survival of moon jellyfish larvae. Mass occurrences of moon jellyfish have imposed socioeconomic impacts on Japanese fishers by clogging and bursting fishing nets. The clogging of seawater intake screens by moon jellyfish has caused such considerable economic damage to power plant companies that it has prompted some companies to hire jellyfish scientists to monitor moon jelly abundance. Multiple sectors therefore exhibit considerable motivation to better predict variations in moon jellyfish populations, but the complex jellyfish life history makes such predictions difficult. The larval stage of the life cycle is presumably of great importance in determining interannual fluctuations in jellyfish abundance. In Japan, the moon jellyfish-spawning period coincides with the summer monsoon season. These extreme rainfall events subject the jellyfish larvae to hyposaline conditions, which are presumed to jeopardize survival because larvae may be sensitive to these abrupt salinity reductions. Furthermore, models of global climate change predict that rainfall events in Japan, including those associated with the monsoon season, will intensify in the next century because of the increased atmospheric moisture. In collaboration with my host scientist, Dr. Shin-Ichi Uye, Professor of Biological Oceanography, Hiroshima University, I conducted a laboratory experiment to determine how exposure to hyposalinity affects survival of the larvae. My results showed that prolonged exposure to hyposaline conditions constrains the development of larvae after the larvae have settled, implying that salinity is a principal factor influencing larval survival in temperate monsoon regions.

The broader impact of the East Asia and the Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) program is the promotion of global awareness of graduate students involved in STEM fields. My EAPSI summer fellowship fulfilled this goal by providing my first exposure to the international jellyfish research community through participation in the 4th International Jellyfish Blooms Symposium, thereby contributing to the development of a globally informed workforce. The EAPSI program afforded me the opportunity to work with one of the world’s leading jellyfish scientists, Dr. Shin Ichi-Uye. While working in the Uye Lab, I formed relationships with fellow graduate students and post-docs from Japan, China, Myanmar, the Philippines, and Slovenia. These relationships will prove instrumental in furthering my career as an internationally engaged scientist.  

The societal relevance of this project lies not only in its collaborative aspects but also in the contextual information the project provided on the societal impacts jellyfish blooms. My host researcher is the principal investigator for a Japanese counter-jellyfish project, “STOPJELLY,” and through this, he has led the development of new methodology to predict and manage jellyfish blooms. During my EAPSI fellowship, I learned the methods that Dr. Uye’s laboratory uses to predict the bloom intensity 1-3 months prior to massive occurrence of jellyfish in Japanese coastal waters, based on on-deck sighting surveys from ferries. This exposure provided a foundation for the way I consider human-jellyfish interactions and has helped me understand how methods may be developed to reduce jellyfish interference with human activities. While in Japan I also learned about the importance of jellyfish as a fishery commodity through touring Japan’s first and largest commercial jellyfish processing facility. Knowledge gained about jellyfish fisheries were presented as a guest lecture to 146 undergraduates in an “Introduction to Oceanography” class at the University of Oregon.
